misconceptions.name: Implemented a completely different problem (average acceleration) instead of sum of even numbers
misconceptions.description: The student code solves a physics-style average acceleration problem: it reads three double values v0, v1, and t, then computes (v1 - v0) / t and prints "The average acceleration is ...". It does not attempt to read 5 integers, does not use a loop, does not check for even numbers, and does not compute or print the sum of even numbers as required.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the task is to read v0, v1, and t and compute the average acceleration (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integers from the user (e.g., using a loop), check each one with n % 2 == 0 to determine if it is even, accumulate the sum of the even numbers only, and then print that sum in the required format (e.g., "Sum of even numbers: 14").
symptoms: Reads three double values instead of five integers.
Variable names and prompt refer to v0, v1, and t, which are unrelated to the problem statement.
No loop is used to process multiple inputs.
No conditional check (n % 2 == 0) is present to filter even numbers.
Output message prints "The average acceleration is ..." instead of the sum of even numbers.
misconceptions.root_cause: Most likely the student copied or submitted a solution for a different textbook exercise (average acceleration) instead of implementing the required sum-of-even-numbers algorithm, indicating a mismatch between problem requirements and implemented code.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and compare it with your program's input prompts, variables, and final output. Then rewrite the program so that it (1) reads 5 integers, preferably in a loop, (2) checks each number with n % 2 == 0, (3) adds only even numbers to a running sum, and (4) prints the sum in the format shown in the sample run.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence because every part of the program (prompt, variable names, formula, and output message) aligns with a known average-acceleration example and none of the required behaviors for summing even numbers are attempted.

evidence.note: This code clearly implements an average acceleration calculation (v1 - v0) / t with a matching prompt and output message, rather than reading 5 integers and summing even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Submitting Code for Incorrect Problem
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code that calculates the average acceleration using three double inputs (v0, v1, t), which is a solution for a different problem, not the required task of reading 5 integers and summing the even numbers. This results in the complete omission of all core requirements: proper input counting, loops, conditional logic, and accumulation.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted a solution intended for a different problem (a physics calculation) or reused an incorrect template, mistakenly believing it satisfies the requirements for summing even numbers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading 5 integer values (using `input.nextInt()`), iterating through them (e.g., using a loop), checking for evenness (using the modulo operator: `n % 2 == 0`), and accumulating the sum.
symptoms: Reads 3 non-integer inputs instead of 5 integers
Calculates a physical formula ((v1 - v0) / t) instead of a summation
Lacks loops and conditional statements required for the task
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to align the implemented code with the task requirements, likely due to submitting the wrong file or fundamentally misunderstanding the scope of the assignment.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully reread the problem statement's requirements: specifically, the number of inputs (5), the type of input (integers), and the required logic (summing only even numbers). Delete the current code and implement the logic using a loop, an accumulator, and an `if` statement.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code solves an entirely different standard formula problem (average acceleration) and shares no code structure or logic with the required summation problem, indicating a complete disconnect from the assignment.

evidence.note: The code prompts for 'v0, v1, and t' and calculates average acceleration, confirming that the student is solving the wrong problem.

misconceptions.name: Implemented a completely different problem (average acceleration) instead of summing even integers
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute average acceleration from v0, v1, and t rather than a program that reads 5 integers, filters evens, sums them, and prints the sum. As a result, none of the required algorithm (loop over 5 integers, even check, accumulator for sum) is present.
misconceptions.student_belief: It appears the student believes the task is to prompt for v0, v1, and t and compute the average acceleration (v1 - v0) / t, not to process 5 integers and sum the even ones.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program should read exactly 5 integers from the user, check each one with n % 2 == 0 to determine if it is even, keep a running total of the even numbers only, and then print the final sum in the required format.
symptoms: Program prompt refers to 'Enter v0, v1, and t' instead of 'Enter 5 integers'
Program reads only 3 values, not 5
Inputs are read as double rather than int
No loop is used to process multiple values
No conditional or modulus operation to test for even numbers
Output message is 'The average acceleration is ...' instead of 'Sum of even numbers: ...'
Computation performed is (v1 - v0) / t, not a sum of even integers
misconceptions.root_cause: Most likely the student copied or reused code for a different textbook problem (average acceleration) or misread the assignment, so they never attempted the required algorithm for summing even integers.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Discard the current physics-related logic and rewrite the program to: (1) prompt for 5 integers, (2) use a loop to read each integer, (3) check if each value is even using n % 2 == 0, (4) add only even values to a running sum, and (5) print 'Sum of even numbers: ' followed by the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (prompt text, variable names, types, calculation, and output) matches a known 'average acceleration' problem and does not implement any part of the requested 'sum of 5 even integers' behavior.

misconceptions.name: Fundamental Task Misunderstanding
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code that solves a completely different problem (physics acceleration calculation) instead of the assigned sum-of-even-numbers problem. This indicates either the student did not read the problem statement, submitted code from a different assignment, or has severe confusion about the task requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the task is to calculate average acceleration using the kinematic formula (v1 - v0) / t with three floating-point inputs.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task is to read 5 integers from the user, identify which ones are even (using the modulo operator: n % 2 == 0), sum only the even numbers, and print the result.
symptoms: Code reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers
Code calculates and prints acceleration instead of sum of even numbers
No loop structure to process 5 separate integers
No conditional logic to check for even numbers
Prompt asks for physics variables (v0, v1, t) instead of integers
misconceptions.root_cause: Student did not carefully read or understand the problem statement; appears to have submitted code from a different assignment or problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Start fresh: (1) Re-read the problem. (2) Use a loop to read 5 integers. (3) Inside the loop, use if (n % 2 == 0) to check if each integer is even. (4) Add even numbers to a sum variable. (5) After the loop, print the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submission solves an entirely different problem with no overlap in algorithm, input requirements, or output format. This is unambiguous evidence of task misunderstanding.
